fields.description:
We are seeing some cases where the session is timed out prematurely. In those cases, it is handled by the container, not our own view code, so we can't control the response. The case where it is problematic is when making XHR calls and we want to return a 403 and some JSON. The container is returning a 200 and the login screen, which is not useful to the client side of that XHR code.
We can push this to after 4.0, but we do need to understand how the session is timing out and how to properly respond to the client. It seems to timeout sooner than we've configured AND the session cookie is still in place, so we know that hasn't expired.

comments.body:
I've been investigating to determine what causes XHR calls to return the login page. I've ruled out code in views/__init__.py (various error catching functions). I've also ruled out the view code that handles the XHR call (since that never gets invoked)
I've noticed the eucaconsole_session cookie's expiration is set to 15 minutes from login (when session.cookie_expires = 900). When the timeout happens, the cookie's expiration is bumped forward another 15 minutes, yet the session is invalid. (at this time, the cookie size drops as well, probably because it doesn't have a session token or other values needed for an active session)
I've put debut in the beaker session.py file for CookieSession and found that the session isn't being deleted or invalidated or expired by functions calls when this event happens.

I'm running instrumented beaker.session code that logs messages in various methods (invalidate, save, etc..). I'm seeing some differences when the cookie expires, but haven't narrowed down to where the code takes a different path on cookie expiration. I can set "session.cookie_expires" back up to 43200 and have not seen any of the timeouts that were initially reported. I will set it back down to continue investigating the code that causes the login page to be returned on a timeout.

I found that login.py defines a "forbidden_view_config" which handles the "403 Forbidden" that is generated when a user's session cookie expires. That code doesn't handle xhr requests properly, so I'm working on that.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/748

I want to point out that I wasn't able to reproduce the unexpected beaker timeout, but I was able to recreate the conditions where a timeout occurs and affects an XHR call. The PR adds support to properly handle this condition for XHR calls, so the client has a chance to properly notify the user of the timeout. This is much better than just hanging.
[~dkavanagh]: Pull request 748 looks good (merged to develop).  Should we leave this ticket open, or is the fix adequate for 4.0.1?

To be sure, I'm not convinced the underlying problem was fixed. beaker.session does timeout when the session cookie expires (using the normal cookie expiration timestamp). I think there were still some "early" timeouts happening that weren't idle-related. At least now, we'll be better able to see the timeout via the modal.
[~dkavanagh]: Ah, ok.  So PR 748 really fixes GUI-263 since we're now displaying a proper notice when a timeout occurs during an XHR request, right?
Pull request 748 merged

[~dkavanagh], [~kgill]: I'm not sure this is fixed.  I did an experiment where I had the browser auto reload the Dashboard every 5 minutes as I was logged into the eucalyptus/admin account.  I returned back to the tab after about an hour in one experiment and when I did a final reload, I was logged out and had to log back in.  I then ran the same experiment but this time came back after a few hours and the browser was logged out.  Is my experiment flawed?  Does the timer get reset if the user reloads a page or does the user have to go to another part of the UI periodically?

I agree that the root problem isn't fixed. In the time I spent looking at this, I didn't determine why the timeout happened. The fix I submitted was primarily to ensure we got proper notification of timeout in some circumstances that made it look like things were "stuck". (see comments above). I think this could be left as an open issue, but moved to the next release. [~jloza]
I agree, let's leave this open and target to 4.0.2 for now (may move to 4.1 in 4.0.2 planning).

[~jloza] this issue is pretty severe in Windows7/FF31 and prevents us from manual testing and running the Selenium tests, since the user is being randomly kicked out after very short period of time. I would recommend fixing it in 4.0.2.
[~alice]: Let's open a separate ticket for the FF 31 on Windows 7 issue, since that appears to be distinct from this issue, since a Beaker session timeout would affect all browsers.
I've instrumented the beaker-session code public methods and am running IDE tests to see if I can get a failure.
any news on this ticket?
I have not seen this recently. I think if [~ccassler] or [~alice] are not seeing this, we could just close it (and re-open should we notice the problem again).
I have not seen this in churns I ran over the week-end on CentOS/FF.
[~jloza], [~dkavanagh]: I have not been able to reproduce this using my refresh tests.
[~dkavanagh], let's go ahead and close this one since it seems to have gone away. (YAY!)...we can always reopen if it reappears. Good news! Thanks everyone!
in 4.2, we may be looking at a different session manger (not beaker).

in demo on 7/2, I kept getting session timeout error, and my console log shows this following:

I checked the images landing page and the image it thinks does not exist is in fact there.
[~jloza]: We have GUI-1846 open for the session timeout issue you experienced during the demo.
[~kgill], I know, I just left comments in both tickets since both have to do with timeouts.
